docs.snippet: Roughly 15 miles separate Connecticut neighbors Yale and Quinnipiac, but both are part of an unlikely group vying for the N.C.A.A. hockey title....
docs.lead_paragraph: Roughly 15 miles separate Connecticut neighbors Yale and Quinnipiac, but both are part of an unlikely group vying for the N.C.A.A. hockey title.
docs.abstract: Yale and Quinnipiac men's ice hockey teams, whose homes are only 15 miles apart in Connecticut, are vying for the NCAA hockey title; Yale will meet Massachusetts-Lowell, while Quinnipiac fames St Cloud State in the Frozen Four.

headline.seo: Miles Apart Back Home, Yale and Quinnipiac Are Together at Frozen Four
headline.main: Miles Apart in Connecticut, Now Even Closer at Frozen Four
headline.print_headline: Miles Apart in Connecticut, Now Even Closer at Frozen Four

docs.snippet: African-Americans make up about 8.5 percent of major league rosters, down from 19 percent in 1986. Are youth travel leagues and college scholarships contributing factors?...
docs.lead_paragraph: African-Americans make up about 8.5 percent of major league rosters, down from 19 percent in 1986. Are youth travel leagues and college scholarships contributing factors?
docs.abstract: Tyler Kepner On Baseball column explores possible reasons for significant decline in African-American major league baseball players, citing lack of Division 1 college scholarships as possibility; notes that 17-member task force led by commissioner Bud Selig is investigating the matter.

headline.seo: Baseball’s Racial Makeup to Be Studied
headline.main: Looking Into the Decline in African-American Players
headline.print_headline: Looking Into the Decline in African-American Players

docs.snippet: After 35 of 44 seniors lost all their artworks in a February fire at the Pratt Institute, benefactors arranged a Manhattan show for them....
docs.lead_paragraph: After 35 of 44 seniors lost all their artworks in a February fire at the Pratt Institute, benefactors arranged a Manhattan show for them.
docs.abstract: Art dealer Larry Gagosian has arranged show featuring new works by Pratt Institute students whose art was destroyed in February fire at institute's historic main building in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; weeklong show will begin at Seagram building in May.

headline.seo: A Showing for Students Who Lost Art at Pratt Institute Fire
headline.main: An Exhibition for Students Who Lost Art in a Studio Fire
headline.print_headline: An Exhibition For Students Who Lost Art In a Studio Fire
